My hope for the "radical redesigned raptor": toggle-able nozzle extension so that a vacuum optimized raptor can retract its nozzle for landing in earth or martian atmosphere without putting the nozzle extension under fluttering aerodynamic strain. This would mean a "starship" would no longer need non-vacuum optimized engines.

33:00 Liftoff

41:25 SECO 1 (from callout)
1:41:54 SES 2
1:42:48 SECO 2
Tim wanted to work on his next video rather than wait for the Payload deploy

Some FAQs from during the stream:

Why was there no landing attempt for this launch?
- Falcon 9 is having to do a lot of work, circularising the final orbit of the satellite, and since the second stage isn't really that efficient had to push some of that load onto the first stage.
- The GPS satellite launched today cost over $500M to build, so a $60M versus $90M launch cost really isn't much.
(There's probably some others)

Could they not have used Falcon Heavy?
Probably, but FH isn't ready yet. Rockets are a little more complex than just cost-per-kilo after all

Why the really long coast until payload deploy?
The payload is under the authority of the US military, and they had to wait for the rocket to orbit round earth into range of one of their ground stations
Elon got a reliable rocket

Information I can't get anywhere but from you, Tim! Stainless steel an interesting choice. First guess: heat sink for reentry. I understand the DynaSoar design used Iconel - a lot of it - so the fuselage gradually soaked up reentry heat. Nothing like the capsule ablative heatshields. (Starship would have heat sink and coating.) But we must also keep in mind: stainless might be a choice just for a test mule, to test Raptors. Quick and dirty one-off fabrication. Elon can be tricky.

I love the conversation between Tim, Elon and Scott Manley. A meeting of great minds.

Would be great to get you all in the same room for a live stream!
Amazing launch !
Respect for streaming the entire thing
